text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Terrorism rears its ugly head with a fourth bomb blast in Lagos; one soldier dead, 29 others injured.
- Alex Akinyele, chairman of national reconciliation committee, says "by God's grace, (detained presidential claimant) Moshood Abiola will be released as soon as possible."
- Shake-up imminent at National Oil and Chemicals Plc, Nigeria's biggest oil marketing company; chief executive retires in May and many executive changes are expected.
- Leader of opposition NADECO group Michael Ajasin calls for thorough investigations into bomb blasts in Lagos; denies his group is involved in any violence.
- Budget 1997 meeting put back to Wednesday as military ruler General Sani Abacha attends inauguration in Accra of Jerry Rawlings as Ghana's elected president for second term.
- Texaco Nigeria Plc oil marketing company opens its new-look fuel depot in Lagos; refurbishments cost 455 million naira.
- Central Bank says it will intervene in autonomous foreign exchange market by selling dollars at market rate of 80 naira each ahead of announcement of fiscal 1997 budget.
- Government may divest from Oku Iboku and Jebba paper mills where its equity holdings are worth five billion naira, industry executives say.
